natural problem: How many perfect squares are two-digit and divisible by $3?$
natural solution: Recall that no perfect squares are negative, because squares of all negative numbers are positive and squares of positive numbers are also positive (and $0^2=0$). Since all perfect squares are either $0$ or positive, the only two-digit perfect squares are: \begin{align}

4^2&=16\\ 5^2&=25\\ 6^2&=36\\ 7^2&=49\\ 8^2&=64\\ 9^2&=81 \end{align} Out of these six perfect squares, only $36$ and $81$ are divisible by $3.$ Note that if a perfect square, $a^2,$ is divisible by $3,$ then $a$ also must have been divisible by $3,$ (as $6$ and $9$ in this case.)
Therefore, $\boxed{2}$ perfect squares are two-digit and divisible by $3.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
shows  "card {n. n \<ge> 10 \<and> n < 100 \<and> (\<exists> k. n = k * k) \<and> n mod 3 = 0} = 2"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many perfect squares are two-digit and divisible by $3?$ The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 Recall that no perfect squares are negative, because squares of all negative numbers are positive and squares of positive numbers are also positive (and $0^2=0$). Since all perfect squares are either $0$ or positive, the only two-digit perfect squares are: \begin{align}
 4^2&=16\\ 5^2&=25\\ 6^2&=36\\ 7^2&=49\\ 8^2&=64\\ 9^2&=81 \end{align} Out of these six perfect squares, only $36$ and $81$ are divisible by $3.$ Note that if a perfect square, $a^2,$ is divisible by $3,$ then $a$ also must have been divisible by $3,$ (as $6$ and $9$ in this case.)
 Therefore, $\boxed{2}$ perfect squares are two-digit and divisible by $3.$
 *)

theorem
shows  "card {n. n \<ge> 10 \<and> n < 100 \<and> (\<exists> k. n = k * k) \<and> n mod 3 = 0} = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: How many square numbers between 10 and 100 are divisible by 3? The final answer is 2.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes perfect_square :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool" and count :: int
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. perfect_square n = (\<exists> m. m * m = n)"
and h1 : "count = card {n. perfect_square n \<and> n > 9 \<and> n < 100 \<and> n mod 3 = 0}"
shows  "count = 2"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many perfect squares are two-digit and divisible by $3?$ The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 Recall that no perfect squares are negative, because squares of all negative numbers are positive and squares of positive numbers are also positive (and $0^2=0$). Since all perfect squares are either $0$ or positive, the only two-digit perfect squares are: \begin{align}
 4^2&=16\\ 5^2&=25\\ 6^2&=36\\ 7^2&=49\\ 8^2&=64\\ 9^2&=81 \end{align} Out of these six perfect squares, only $36$ and $81$ are divisible by $3.$ Note that if a perfect square, $a^2,$ is divisible by $3,$ then $a$ also must have been divisible by $3,$ (as $6$ and $9$ in this case.)
 Therefore, $\boxed{2}$ perfect squares are two-digit and divisible by $3.$
 *)

theorem
fixes perfect_square :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool" and count :: int
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. perfect_square n = (\<exists> m. m * m = n)"
and h1 : "count = card {n. perfect_square n \<and> n > 9 \<and> n < 100 \<and> n mod 3 = 0}"
shows  "count = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: How many perfect squares between 10 and 99 are divisible by 3? The final answer is 2.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes perfect_squares :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "perfect_squares = {n^2 |n. n \<in> {1..31}}"
and h1 : "{n \<in> perfect_squares. n \<ge> 10 \<and> n < 100 \<and> n mod 3 = 0} = {x, y}"
shows  "card {x, y} = 2"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 ### Proof

 Therefore, $\boxed{2}$ perfect squares are two-digit and divisible by $3.$
 *)

fixes perfect_squares :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "perfect_squares = {n^2 |n. n \<in> {1..31}}"
and h1 : "{n \<in> perfect_squares. n \<ge> 10 \<and> n < 100 \<and> n mod 3 = 0} = {x, y}"
shows  "card {x, y} = 2"
 proof-

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. x \<in> {a..b} \<longrightarrow> (x mod 3 = 0 \<and> sqrt x \<in> Nats)"
shows  "card {a..b} = 2"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many perfect squares are two-digit and divisible by $3?$ The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 Recall that no perfect squares are negative, because squares of all negative numbers are positive and squares of positive numbers are also positive (and $0^2=0$). Since all perfect squares are either $0$ or positive, the only two-digit perfect squares are: \begin{align}
 4^2&=16\\ 5^2&=25\\ 6^2&=36\\ 7^2&=49\\ 8^2&=64\\ 9^2&=81 \end{align} Out of these six perfect squares, only $36$ and $81$ are divisible by $3.$ Note that if a perfect square, $a^2,$ is divisible by $3,$ then $a$ also must have been divisible by $3,$ (as $6$ and $9$ in this case.)
 Therefore, $\boxed{2}$ perfect squares are two-digit and divisible by $3.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. x \<in> {a..b} \<longrightarrow> (x mod 3 = 0 \<and> sqrt x \<in> Nats)"
shows  "card {a..b} = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: In the set of natural numbers from $a$ to $b$, there are only two numbers that are divisible by 3 and whose square roots are also natural numbers. What are $a$ and $b$?

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<ge> 10"
and h1 : "n \<le> 99"
and h2 : "n mod 3 = 0"
and h3 : "\<exists> m. m * m = n"
shows  "card {n. n \<ge> 10 \<and> n \<le> 99 \<and> n mod 3 = 0 \<and> (\<exists> m. m * m = n)} = 2"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many perfect squares are two-digit and divisible by $3?$ The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 Recall that no perfect squares are negative, because squares of all negative numbers are positive and squares of positive numbers are also positive (and $0^2=0$). Since all perfect squares are either $0$ or positive, the only two-digit perfect squares are: \begin{align}
 4^2&=16\\ 5^2&=25\\ 6^2&=36\\ 7^2&=49\\ 8^2&=64\\ 9^2&=81 \end{align} Out of these six perfect squares, only $36$ and $81$ are divisible by $3.$ Note that if a perfect square, $a^2,$ is divisible by $3,$ then $a$ also must have been divisible by $3,$ (as $6$ and $9$ in this case.)
 Therefore, $\boxed{2}$ perfect squares are two-digit and divisible by $3.$
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<ge> 10"
and h1 : "n \<le> 99"
and h2 : "n mod 3 = 0"
and h3 : "\<exists> m. m * m = n"
shows  "card {n. n \<ge> 10 \<and> n \<le> 99 \<and> n mod 3 = 0 \<and> (\<exists> m. m * m = n)} = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the number of whole numbers between 10 and 99, inclusive, that are divisible by 3 and are perfect squares. The final answer is 2.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<ge> 10"
and h1 : "n \<le> 99"
shows  "card {x. x \<in> {n. n \<ge> 10 \<and> n \<le> 99 \<and> is_square n} \<and> x mod 3 = 0} = 2"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many perfect squares are two-digit and divisible by $3?$ The final Answer is 2

 Recall that no perfect squares are negative, because squares of all negative numbers are positive and squares of positive numbers are also positive (and $0^2=0$). Since all perfect squares are either $0$ or positive, the only two-digit perfect squares are: \begin{align}

 Therefore, $\boxed{2}$ perfect squares are two-digit and divisible by $3.$
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<ge> 10"
and h1 : "n \<le> 99"
shows  "card {x. x \<in> {n. n \<ge> 10 \<and> n \<le> 99 \<and> is_square n} \<and> x mod 3 = 0} = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: How many square numbers between 10 and 99 inclusive are divisible by 3? The final answer is 2.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
shows  "{x. x \<in> {10..99} \<and> (\<exists> y. y * y = x \<and> x mod 3 = 0)} = {36, 81}"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many perfect squares are two-digit and divisible by $3?$ The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 Recall that no perfect squares are negative, because squares of all negative numbers are positive and squares of positive numbers are also positive (and $0^2=0$). Since all perfect squares are either $0$ or positive, the only two-digit perfect squares are: \begin{align}

 Therefore, $\boxed{2}$ perfect squares are two-digit and divisible by $3.$
 *)

theorem
shows  "{x. x \<in> {10..99} \<and> (\<exists> y. y * y = x \<and> x mod 3 = 0)} = {36, 81}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find all two-digit numbers that are squares of some number and are divisible by 3. The final answer is the set {36, 81}.
